Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply modelled with main features of head, elytra indicated by single lines, but some details might have disappeared since back very rubbed; at side, thick legs simply and crudely modelled, with undercut triangle; underside incised with hieroglyphic signs (Maat feather, sun-disc and neb-basket sign recognisable) arranged horizontally; some hatching within signs; pierced longitudinally; in fine pale yellow paste; worn surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scarab is published as coming from Naukratis (Budge 1893, no.186). Most signs are legible, but reading is difficult: the hieroglyphs are possibly only used here for their intrinsic magical value, as often for this type of scarab (Gorton 1996, 93). Although this specific motif is not listed by Gorton, it could pertain to her type XXXIV A (Gorton 1996, 121-123). The style and technique applied to the motif, as well as the general shape and treatment of the scarab fit well with this type. Similar inscribed scarabs with no real sense to the inscription: e.g. BM 1886,0401.1670; Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.12. Budge, E.A.W. 1893, Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Budge 1893b / Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum (no. 186)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.126) (phase 3)
